channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden Is Hoping Small Changes Go a Long Way on Immigration
item.description: The United States has started to allow people to apply for asylum under a new process that the secretary of homeland security hopes can help fix the current “very broken system.”
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Migrants walked out of the Rio Grande this month to turn themselves in to U.S. Border Patrol agents and request asylum in El Paso.

item.title: Biden Says Social Security Is on ‘Chopping Block’ if Republicans Win Congress
item.description: The fate of America’s social safety net programs has re-emerged as a campaign issue ahead of November’s midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s comments on Tuesday were part of a push by Democrats to steer the political conversation away from growing recession fears.

item.title: Senate Advances Measure to Avert Government Shutdown
item.description: The vote on Tuesday came after Senator Joe Manchin agreed to leave out a plan to make it easier to build energy infrastructure projects, including a gas pipeline in his home state of West Virginia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Funding for the government is set to run out when a new fiscal year begins on Saturday.

item.title: Lawsuit Seeks to Block Biden’s Student Debt Cancellation Plan
item.description: A lawyer at a conservative legal group said in a complaint that he would personally be financially harmed by the government’s approach.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s proposed plan would cancel up to $20,000 per borrower in federal student loan debt.

item.title: For a Deaf Family in Ukraine, War Is a Bewildering Terror
item.description: People with disabilities in the country are often isolated and poor, and for those like Antonina Andriyenko and her daughter, Tanya, the fear and confusion of trying to stay safe is a constant struggle.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonina Andriyenko, 74, on the balcony of her apartment in Kharkiv, Ukraine, in July. “We stayed because we didn’t know where to go,” she said.

item.title: Taken Under Fascism, Spain’s ‘Stolen Babies’ Are Learning the Truth
item.description: Thousands of Spanish children were taken from hospitals and sold to wealthy Catholic families. This is Ana Belén Pintado’s story.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Lydia Metral for The New York Times. Source photograph from Ana Belén Pintado.
item.media:description: Ana Belén Pintado as a young girl.

item.title: McConnell Endorses Electoral Count Overhaul, Lifting Chances of Enactment
item.description: The Republican leader’s backing enhanced prospects for legislation drafted to prevent a repeat of the Jan. 6 assault, when rioters tried to pressure the vice president to overturn the election.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell on Tuesday announced his support of legislation to overhaul how Congress counts electoral votes.

item.title: Are Political Winds Blowing in Republicans’ Favor Again?
item.description: There are some signs of a drift toward issues where the party has an advantage, like the economy and immigration.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Food prices, stock prices and other economic factors may be top priorities for voters in November.

item.title: Roger Stone Encouraged Violence, Sought Pardon After Riot, Jan. 6 Evidence Shows
item.description: The texts from Mr. Stone are among the evidence expected to be presented at the House investigative committee’s next hearing, which was postponed because of Hurricane Ian.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House committee investigating the attack on the Capitol has not held a hearing since July. It has not determined whether the next one will be its last.

item.title: Photos Show NASA’s DART Spacecraft Crashing Into Asteroid
item.description: Astronomers on Earth — and a shoebox-size Italian spacecraft called LICIACube — captured the DART mission’s successful strike on Dimorphos.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: ASI/NASA

item.title: The Dazzling Life and Shocking Death of Cheslie Kryst
item.description: A beauty queen, an attorney, a TV star whose suicide was a reminder of a troubling uptick in mental health struggles among women and in the Black community.
item.dc:creator: Dodai Stewart
item.media:credit: Paras Griffin/Getty Images

item.title: The Gottmans’ New Book Tries to Fix Your Marriage In 7 Days
item.description: The renowned love researchers have been happily wed for decades. Would following the advice in their new book improve my own relationship?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Marta Monteiro

item.title: The Forgotten Lessons of the Recovered Memory Movement
item.description: A deep understanding of how cultural trends and psychology interact is more important than ever.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Watters
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mike McQuade. Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Bring On the Women’s Revolutions
item.description: A regime that will not give relief to women deserves no relief from sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Russians Are Terrified and Have Nowhere to Turn
item.description: For citizens who want to escape conscription, there simply aren’t many options.
item.dc:creator: Ilia Krasilshchik
item.media:credit: Arkady Budnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Conscripted Russian men attending a farewell ceremony in Bataysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Why Putin’s War Is a Crime Against the Planet
item.description: To fully see the destructive impact of the Ukraine war, listen to the Indigenous people who are guardians of some of the world’s remote ecosystems.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: What’s Behind the British Pound’s Decline?
item.description: One surprising factor may be home mortgages.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Pool and Mykola Sosiukin via Getty Images

item.title: Ron DeSantis Is Making an Asylum Crisis of His Own
item.description: Does America still embrace its international obligation to provide sanctuary to at least some unauthorized immigrants?
item.dc:creator: Dara Lind
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Xuanyu Han and Gwengoat, via Getty Images

item.title: Jamie Raskin on The Second Amendment
item.description: It is essential to reject the myth that frustrated citizens have a right to raise arms against the government.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Raskin
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Nicole Hester/Ann Arbor News, via Associated Press

item.title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Alexandre Meneghini/Reuters
item.media:description: Hurricane Ian hit Cuba this morning, causing flooding and power outages

item.title: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
item.description: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
item.media:credit: Irina Rozovsky for The New York Times

item.title: A Doctor Burns Out: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Who pays for climate havoc?
item.description: There’s growing grievance against a global system that saddles developing countries with debt after extreme weather disasters.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: The wreckage of a home in Codrington, Barbuda, in December 2017.

item.title: Trump Might Escape E. Jean Carroll’s Suit Because He Was President
item.description: E. Jean Carroll’s case may fail thanks to broad protections granted to federal officials and employees. She still plans to file a separate suit accusing the ex-president of rape.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: The court found that Donald J. Trump, who E. Jean Carroll said lied about raping her, should be considered a federal employee.

item.title: Keir Starmer Accuses Liz Truss of Losing Control of Britain’s Economy
item.description: Under the governing Conservatives, the markets are down and the pound is under pressure. On Tuesday, Keir Starmer, the Labour leader, staked his claim as the guardian of sound fiscal policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, used his party conference speech on Tuesday in Liverpool to talk about how his party would try to solve the economic crisis.

item.title: Inflation Has Hit Tenants Hard. What About Their Landlords?
item.description: Publicly traded corporate landlords are reporting some of their highest margins ever, while smaller operators say rent increases are eaten up by costs.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Richard Beaven for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ryan Vienneau and his wife own 11 apartments in and around Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

item.title: Ilse Nathan and Ruth Siegler, Sisters and Survivors Together, Die 11 Days Apart
item.description: They stood by each other at Birkenau, married other Holocaust survivors, lived near each other in Alabama and remained close into their 90s.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: The Health Benefits of Chia Seeds
item.description: Chia seeds are back (again) — and nutritionists and doctors say there are good reasons for it.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Adam Friedlander for The New York Times

item.title: Is It Better to Cook With Coconut Oil or Olive Oil?
item.description: Proponents of coconut oil point out that it is rich in phytochemicals with healthful properties. But so is olive oil.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: How Much Sugar Is in a Glass of Wine?
item.description: Winemakers may add sugar to wine to “improve” the taste, and sugar content can vary widely.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times

item.title: Is Alkaline Water Really Better for You?
item.description: What’s behind the claims that alkaline water will “energize” and “detoxify” the body and lead to “superior hydration”?
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:credit: iStock

item.title: Testosterone Levels: Can Specific Foods or Diets Boost Them?
item.description: What you eat or drink may affect levels of the male sex hormone, but whether a diet can increase libido or energy depends on many things.
item.dc:creator: Randi Hutter Epstein, M.D.
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: In Malibu, an Inflatable Bungalow for Robert Downey Jr.
item.description: The actor’s thin-shell home is at once an aerodynamic oddity and, perhaps, a harbinger of environmentally conscious architecture.
item.dc:creator: Nick Haramis and Joyce Kim
item.media:credit: Joyce Kim
item.media:description: The Downeys’ 6,500-square-foot Binishell nearly disappears into the surrounding landscape.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
